title: Srimad Bhagavatam - Canto 1 Chapter 2 | Teens Quiz (20Q)

questions.prompt: According to SB 1.2.2, what is the ultimate test of a bona fide spiritual master?
choices: He possesses academic degrees in theology
He can cure the disciple of material disease (lust, anger, greed)
He belongs to an ancient lineage only
questions.feedback: The verse establishes a therapeutic criterion: the guru must cure the disciple's material disease. This guards against mistaking credentials, charisma, or institutional position for authentic spiritual authority.

questions.prompt: What happens when a devotee continuously hears about Vasudeva (SB 1.2.3)?
choices: Bhakti is established in the heart and material desires diminish proportionately
questions.feedback: The verse presents gradual, proportionate purification through continuous hearing. This realistic medical model prevents both magical expectations and cynical dismissal of the process.

questions.prompt: According to SB 1.2.6, what defines the highest dharma for humanity?
choices: Perfect execution of varna-ashrama duties regardless of intent
That which leads to causeless, uninterrupted devotional service to the transcendent Lord
questions.feedback: Dharma is redefined not as rule-compliance but by its outcome: does it cultivate bhakti? This revolutionary criterion judges activities by their fruit (devotional transformation), not their form (ritual correctness).

questions.prompt: What is the exclusive activity prescribed for those desiring liberation in SB 1.2.7?
choices: Inquiring submissively about the Absolute Truth from one who knows
questions.feedback: The verse establishes epistemological exclusivity—inquiry into the Absolute Truth is not optional but the only truly necessary engagement. This challenges the modern assumption of 'balanced' life with spirituality as one component among many.

questions.prompt: According to SB 1.2.8, what three-fold result occurs when one fully engages in hearing and chanting?
choices: Wealth, fame, and power are acquired
The knot of false ego is cut, doubts are cleared, and karmic reactions cease
One achieves temporary peace but must repeat the process
questions.feedback: The verse presents comprehensive cure: (1) false identification dissolved, (2) epistemic certainty through realization, (3) liberation from action-reaction. This is ontological transformation, not symptom management.

questions.prompt: What does 'unmotivated' (ahaituki) devotional service mean in SB 1.2.9?
choices: Service free from desire for material gain, sense pleasure, or even liberation
questions.feedback: Ahaituki means causeless—not seeking economic gain, pleasure, powers, or liberation. Even desire for liberation can be refined selfishness. Pure bhakti transcends all calculations, serving for the Lord's pleasure alone.

questions.prompt: How does SB 1.2.10 resolve the paradox of desire?
choices: By eliminating all desires through force
By redirecting desire to Krishna's service, which satisfies the self's constitutional need
By moderating desires to reasonable levels
By accepting that desires can never be satisfied
questions.feedback: The verse teaches that desires are satisfied not by fulfillment or suppression, but by correct direction. The living entity is constitutionally a servant; serving Krishna satisfies the self because it engages us in our natural function.

questions.prompt: SB 1.2.11 states that learned transcendentalists know the Absolute Truth as three features. What are they?
questions.feedback: The famous verse establishes three features of the nondual Absolute: Brahman (impersonal all-pervading), Paramatma (localized Supersoul), and Bhagavan (Supreme Personality). These are progressive realizations of one truth, not three separate entities.

questions.prompt: Why does the purport to SB 1.2.11 establish Bhagavan realization as most complete?
choices: Because it is the easiest path
Because realizing the personal feature includes understanding the impersonal and localized features
Because it requires less philosophical understanding
questions.feedback: One who realizes Bhagavan automatically understands Brahman and Paramatma, but not vice versa. This establishes hierarchy of completeness, not mere difference. Knowing the sun includes knowing sunshine and its localized presence.

questions.prompt: According to SB 1.2.12, from whom must we learn to understand the science of God?
choices: From academic scholars of religious studies
From a tattva-darsi—one who has seen the truth, not merely studied it
From anyone who speaks eloquently about philosophy
questions.feedback: The verse insists on learning from one who has realized the truth (tattva-darsi), not merely collected information. Book learning without realization cannot transmit transcendental knowledge. This distinguishes spiritual authority from academic credentials.

questions.prompt: What is the primary qualification for hearing transcendental narrations according to SB 1.2.17?
questions.feedback: Sraddha (faith) is the foundational qualification, more essential than intelligence, birth, or renunciation. Faith is not blind acceptance but trusting receptivity that allows transcendental truth to be received, not forced open by hostile skepticism.

questions.prompt: According to SB 1.2.18, what does Krishna do when one regularly hears about Him with faith?
choices: He becomes seated in the heart and cuts through material desires
He tests the devotee with more suffering
questions.feedback: Krishna personally enters the heart and performs purification. This reveals the essential asymmetry of bhakti: the devotee makes small effort (faithful hearing), Krishna reciprocates with disproportionate mercy (internal transformation). We can't self-purify, but sincere hearing invites divine intervention.

questions.prompt: What does SB 1.2.19 say the devotee is freed from as bhakti progresses?
choices: Rajas and tamas, becoming fixed in sattva-guna
questions.feedback: The verse indicates progressive purification: first eliminating passion and ignorance, becoming steady in goodness. This is realistic staging, preventing both complacency (thinking one is already pure) and discouragement (expecting instant perfection).

questions.prompt: In SB 1.2.20, what dual realization occurs for the devotee in transcendental goodness?
choices: Knowledge of the self as eternal servant and knowledge of the Supreme Lord
Understanding of past and future lives
questions.feedback: The verse presents both self-knowledge (eternal servant) and God-knowledge (eternal master) in clear relationship. This double realization produces lasting happiness because ontological confusion is resolved. Bhakti provides both terms of the equation.

questions.prompt: According to SB 1.2.21, what does bhakti-yoga eliminate?
choices: The threefold miseries: from body/mind, other beings, and natural disturbances
The need to maintain the body
questions.feedback: Bhakti addresses the root of suffering—separation from Krishna—thus eliminating all derivative sufferings. External difficulties may occur, but they lose power to create existential anguish. This is liberation within life, not escape from circumstances.

questions.prompt: What kind of knowledge manifests as bhakti matures, according to SB 1.2.22?
choices: Scientific knowledge (tattva-jnanam) of the self and the Absolute
questions.feedback: The verse specifies 'scientific' (tattva-jnanam) knowledge—precise, verifiable understanding of reality. This guards against reducing bhakti to sentimentalism. Authentic devotion produces knowledge—clear, systematic understanding that satisfies both heart and intellect.

questions.prompt: According to SB 1.2.24, what is the correct sequence of the devotional path?
choices: Hearing → attachment to Krishna → liberation from hankering → detachment from matter
questions.feedback: The verse reverses the jnana path: first cultivate attachment to Krishna (through hearing), then detachment from matter follows naturally. This is the positive path of higher taste versus the negative path of forced renunciation. Psychologically realistic and accessible to all.

questions.prompt: Why should the body be maintained, according to SB 1.2.26?
choices: For inquiry about the Absolute Truth and realizing one's relationship with the Supreme
questions.feedback: The body's purpose is self-realization and understanding our relationship with Krishna. Even animals maintain bodies for eating, sleeping, mating, defending; human life must have a higher purpose. The body is neither the self nor to be abused, but a vehicle for spiritual inquiry.

questions.prompt: What is the root misconception that devotional service destroys, according to SB 1.2.30?
choices: The false identification 'I am this body' and 'This is mine'
questions.feedback: Bhakti attacks the root illusion—false bodily identification and possessiveness. When one realizes 'I am not this body; I am eternal servant of Krishna,' all other misconceptions dissolve. Body and possessions are seen as Krishna's property held in trust, eliminating anxiety.

questions.prompt: Synthesizing Chapter 2: Why is bhakti presented as supreme over karma, jnana, and yoga?
choices: Because it is the easiest path requiring no effort
Because it alone satisfies the self, grants complete knowledge, and liberates naturally through attraction rather than force
Because it is more ancient and traditional
Because other paths are completely invalid
questions.feedback: Bhakti's supremacy rests on integration: (1) it satisfies the self's constitutional need to serve, (2) it grants complete knowledge of Bhagavan (not just partial realizations), (3) it liberates through natural attraction to Krishna rather than forced renunciation. This addresses both philosophical necessity (what is true) and practical efficacy (what actually works for fallen souls in Kali-yuga). The synthesis question tests whether the student grasps the cumulative argument across epistemology, ontology, and soteriology.
